sen.j: 明経道（みょうぎょうどう）は、日本律令制の大学寮において儒学を研究・教授した学科。
sen.e: Myogyodo is a department of Daigakuryo, an educational institution under the system of centralized administration established under the ritsuryo legal codes in Japan, in which was studied and taught the Confucianism.

Myoygodo was a department that studied and instructed on Confucianism as part the Daigakuryo, an educational institution under the system of centralized administration established by the ritsuryo legal codes of Japan.
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence to read more naturally
sen.e: Myogyodo was a department that studied and instructed on Confucianism as part the Daigakuryo, an educational institution under the Ritsuryo system (the system of centralized administration established by the ritsuryo legal codes) of Japan.
sen.cmt: 律令制 追加しました。

sen.j: 元来大学の本科にあたり、特別の名称はなかった。
sen.e: It was originally the regular course of the institute and had no particular name.
It was originally a regular course in the institute and had no particular name.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar
sen.e: It was originally a regular course in the institute and had no particular name.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 儒学の研究を明経と呼ぶ例は奈良時代からあったが、平安時代前期に大学の各学科が「道」（紀伝道・明法道・算道・書道など）と呼ばれるようになると、明経道という呼称が定着した。
sen.e: The study of Confucianism was sometimes called Myogyo since the Nara period and because the other departments started to be called 'do' (such as Kidendo, Myohodo, Sando, Syodo) in the early Heian period, the name Myogyodo became popular, too.

From the Nara period, the study of Confucianism was sometimes called Myogyo, but as other departments came to end with the suffix "-do" (the character used was "道" literally meaning "the way") (such as Kidendo, Myohodo, Sando and Shodo) during the early Heian period, Myogo came to be called Myogyodo.
sen.cmt: added description for "do"; changed "Syodo" to "Shodo"; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: From the Nara period, the study of Confucianism was sometimes called Myogyo, but as other departments came to end with the suffix '-do' (the character used was "道" literally meaning "the way") (such as Kidendo [study of the histories], Myohodo [study of codes], Sando [study of mathematics] and Shodo [calligraphy]) during the early Heian period, Myogyo came to be called Myogyodo.
sen.cmt: " → ' としました。紀伝道、明法道などの補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 明経博士1名・助教2名・直講2名の各教官と、明経得業生（みょうぎょうとくぎょうしょう）4名・明経生（みょうぎょうしょう）400名から成るが、学生定員は平安時代を通じて充足されることはなかった。
sen.e: It consisted of a Doctor of Myogyo, 2 assistant professors, 2 lecturers and 4 people of Myogyo Tokugyosyo (honour students) and 400 people of Myogyosyo (students) and the fixed number of students was never increased through the Heian period.

The Myogyodo department consisted of a Myogyo hakase (Professor of Confucianism), two assistant professors, four Myogyo Tokugyosho (honor students) and four-hundred Myogyosho (students). The number of students was fixed and never increased throughout the Heian period.
sen.cmt: split into two sentences for better flow; changed "Doctor of Myogyo" to "Myogo hakase" and added description; typed out numerals; changed "honour" to "honor"; changed "Tokugosyo" to "Tokugyosho"; changed "Myogyosyo" to "Myogyosho"; fixed grammar
sen.e: The Myogyodo department consisted of a Myogyo hakase (Professor of Confucianism), two assistant professors, four Myogyo Tokugyosho (honor students) and 400 Myogyosho (students); the number of students was fixed and never increased throughout the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 一文につなげました。

sen.j: 教科書は平安時代に三経（詩経・書経・易経）、三礼（周礼・儀礼・礼記）、三伝（春秋左氏伝・春秋公羊伝・春秋穀梁伝）及び『論語』『孝経』の１１経が主な教材として確立された。
sen.e: The following 11 books were established as the major textbooks in the Heian period: Sankyo (Shikyo, Shokyo, Ekikyo), Sanrai (Shurai, Girai, Raiki), Sanden (Syunju Sashiden, Syunju Kuyoden, Syunju Kokuryoden), "Rongo", "Kokyo".

The following eleven books were established as the major Myogyo textbooks during the Heian period: the three Sankyo called Shikyo, Shokyo and Ekikyo; the three Sanrai called Shurai, Girai and Raiki; the three Sanden called Shunju Sashiden, Shunju Kuyoden and Shunju Kokuryoden; as well as the "Rongo" and "Kokyo."
sen.cmt: eliminated parenthesis and used semicolons for easier understanding (it looked to me like there are 14 books using parenthesis); changed "Syu" to "Shu" in all cases
sen.e: The following eleven books were established as the major Myogyo textbooks during the Heian period: the three Sankyo (three classics on Confucianism) called Shikyo, Shokyo and Ekikyo; the three Sanrai (three classical texts on rites) called Shurai, Girai and Raiki; the three Sanden (three classics on a Chinese history book "Shunju") called Shunju Sashiden, Shunju Kuyoden and Shunju Kokuryoden; as well as the "Rongo" and "Kokyo."
sen.cmt: 三経、三礼、三伝 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: そして必修である『論語』『孝経』の他に最低二経を学習した明経生は明経試（後に明経得業試に改められた）に受験・合格してから叙位・任官するのが原則だったが、明経試を経ないで叙位・任官するケースも多かったらしい。
sen.e: Those who studied at least two books other than the compulsory books, "Rongo" and "Kokyo, were likely to be able to confer a rank and be appointed without Myogyoshi (later revised as Myogyo Tokugyoshi) (the Myogyo examination) often, while in principle, students were conferred a rank and appointed after passed the Myogyo examination.

Although it was a general rule that students needed to study the two compulsory books "Rongo" and "Kokyo" and pass the Myogyoshi (the Myogyo examination - later revised into the "Myogyo Tokugyoshi") before being appointed and conferred a rank, there were many reported cases of students receiving their rank and appointment without taking the test.
sen.cmt: rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Although it was a general rule that students needed to study at least two books other than the two compulsory books "Rongo" and "Kokyo" and pass the Myogyoshi (the Myogyo examination - later revised into the "Myogyo Tokugyoshi") before being appointed and conferred a rank, there were many reported cases of students receiving their rank and appointment without taking the test.
sen.cmt: 最低二経→at least two other books を追加しました。

sen.j: 明経試は必修の2経から計3問と他の2経から3または4問出されて計10問から出題され、6問以上合格する必要があった。
sen.e: In the Myogyo examination, total 10 questions were asked including 3 questions from 2 compulsory books and 3 or 4 questions from other 2 books and students had to pass more than 6 questions.

There were a total of ten questions in the Myogyo examination, three questions from each of the two compulsory books and three or four questions from two other books. In order to pass the test, students were required to correctly answer six questions.
sen.cmt: split into two sentences; typed out numerals; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: There were a total of ten questions in the Myogyo examination, three questions from each of the two compulsory books and three or four questions from two other books; in order to pass the test, students were required to correctly answer six questions.
sen.cmt: 一文につなげました。

sen.j: 平安時代初期には三礼学派・三伝学派という流れが成立して両者の間で論争が行われたが、平安時代中期以降は明経道そのものが儒教の専門家養成コースのような性格を持つようになって学術論争が沈滞していった。
sen.e: In the early Heian period, Sanraigaku school and Sandengaku school appeared and there were arguments between them, but after the middle of the Heian period Myogyodo itself became a kind of training course for professional Confucian and therefore the arguments calmed down.

During the early Heian period, Myogyodo separated into the two schools called "Sanraigaku" and "Sandengaku" and debates took place between them. The arguments stagnated after the middle of the Heian period, however, once Myogyodo itself came to have the characteristics of a training course for becoming a professional on Confucianism.
sen.cmt: split into two sentences for easier reading; added quotation marks around the two different branches of study; changed "calmed down" to "stagnated" for "沈滞"; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: During the early Heian period, Myogyodo separated into the two schools called "Sanraigaku" and "Sandengaku" and debates took place between them; the arguments stagnated after the middle of the Heian period, however, once Myogyodo itself came to have the characteristics of a training course for becoming a professional on Confucianism.
sen.cmt: 一文につなげました。

sen.j: また、その地位も紀伝道を掌る文章博士（元は明経道に附属して直講1名が回されたもの）の地位が上昇して明経博士を追い越したために本科としての地位を失った。
sen.e: Also it lost the position as the regular course because the position of Doctor of Monjo (originally attached to Myogyo with one lecturer) who handled Kidendo was place higher than the Doctor of Myogyo.

Myogyodo lost its position as a regular course due to the position of Monjo hakase (Professor of Literature; a position that was originally affiliated with Myogyodo as a lecturer), who handled Kidendo, was placed higher than Myogyo hakase.

sen.e: Myogyodo lost its position as a regular course due to the position of Monjo hakase (Professor of Literature; a position that was originally affiliated with Myogyodo as a lecturer), who handled Kidendo, was placed higher than Myogyo hakase.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: それでも、明経道の本科としての意識は強く、明経博士を務めた十市有象（中原氏の祖）による安和2年（969年）の解文には、紀伝道と明法道を「小道」と非難する一文が載せられている（『類聚符宣抄』所収）。
sen.e: Myogyodo still had a strong sense as the regular course and in 969 the Myogyo Doctor, Yuzo Toichi (十市有象) (the first person of Nakahara clan) wrote an official letter including a sentence to criticize Kidendo and Myohodo as 'small course' (it is included in "Ruiju Fusensho").
sen.cmt: 十市有象の正しい読み方不明
sen.e: Even so, Myogyodo retained itself as a regular course. In 969, a Myogyo hakase named Yuzo Toichi (十市有象) (the first of the Nakahara clan) wrote an official letter that included a sentence criticizing Kidendo and Myohodo as "small courses" (this letter is included in "Ruiju Fusensho").
sen.cmt: split into two sentences; changed "Myogyo Doctor" to "Myogyo hakase"; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Even so, Myogyodo retained itself as a regular course, and in 969, a Myogyo hakase named Yuzo Toichi (十市有象) (the founder of the Nakahara clan) wrote an official letter that included a sentence criticizing Kidendo and Myohodo as 'small courses' (this letter is included in "Ruiju Fusensho" [A collection of official documents dating from the years 737 to 1093]).
sen.cmt: 『類聚符宣抄』 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: また、文章生など他の学生に対しても一般常識としての儒学教養を求めたために他学生による明経道の講義の聴講が行われる場合が多かった。
sen.e: Also other departments' students such as Monjo were required to study Confucianism as general education subject, therefore the lectures of Myogyodo were often taken by them.
Furthermore, there were many cases of students from other departments, such as Monjo (Literature), taking courses on Confucianism since the subejct had become a required general subject.
sen.cmt: changed "Also" to "Furthermore"; added description for "Monjo"; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Furthermore, there were many cases of students from other departments, such as Monjo (Literature), taking courses on Myogyodo since the subject had become a required general subject.
sen.cmt: Confucianism →Myogyodo としました。

sen.j: また、正暦4年（993年）には、明経博士中原致時の申請によって明経得業生に准じる地位として、8から10名でなる明経問者生が設置されて、試験に合格すれば得業生に准じる資格で官吏になることが出来た。
sen.e: Also in 993, Doctor of Myogyo, NAKAHARA no Munetoki applied to put 8 – 10 people as Myogyo Monjasei and as the result of that, they could have the qualification to be government officials like Tokugyosho if they passed the examination.

In 993, as a result of the Myogyo hakase NAKAHARA no Munetoki applying to put eight to ten students in the position of Myogyo Monjasho (students in a secondary position to Tokugyosho), these students were able to receive qualification as government officials like Tokugyosho if they passed the examination.
sen.cmt: changed "Monjasei" to "Monjasho" due to the wiki article on "問者生" giving this reading, added description as well; fixed grammar
sen.e: In 993, as a result of the Myogyo hakase NAKAHARA no Munetoki applying to put eight to ten students in the position of Myogyo Monjasho (students in a secondary position to Tokugyosho), these students were able to receive qualification as government officials like Tokugyosho if they passed the examination.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: やがて明経道の教官職は中原氏・清原氏による世襲が事実上慣例化し、明経道そのものも専ら訓詁学研究に終始したようである。
sen.e: Later the lecturers of Myogyodo were inherited by Nakahara and Kiyohara clan conventionally in effect, and Myogyodo itself also became the study of Kunkogaku (annotation and interpretation of Classical books).

Before long, the position of Myogyodo lecturer became conventionally inherited by the Nakahara and Kiyohara clans and Myogyodo itself became the study of Kunkogaku (annotation and interpretation of classical books) as well.

sen.j: 江戸時代には清原氏の子孫である舟橋家・伏原家が博士の職を世襲したが、儒教の中でも新興の宋学全盛の時代にあっては名目のみの官となっていった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Funabashi family and Fusehara family who were the descendants of Nakahara clan inherited the Doctor, but it was in name only while Sogaku, an emerging Confucianism was in the golden days.

During the Edo period, the Funabashi and Fusehara families, as descendants of the Nakahara clan, inherited the position of hakase (professor). The inherited position was in name only, however, since it had become the golden days of the newly emerged Sogaku (Song-period neo-Confusianism).
